title: Extinction Rebellion to shut down London for a fortnight with 30,000 to protest
text:

More than 1,000 people came together this evening for an opening ceremony ahead of two weeks of Extinction Rebellion protests.

From Monday onwards, activists will shut down large tracts of London in protests organisers pledge will be five times bigger than the ones in April.

Extinction Rebellion are demanding the government acts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2025 through the medium of peaceful but disruptive protests.

Today demonstrators held hands at Marble Arch alongside members of the Red Brigade, a performance group who have appeared in their distinctive robes at previous protests.

(Image: PA)

When the eco-warriors arrive on the streets of London tomorrow they will gather at 11 points across the capital including Westminster and Lambeth Bridges, Parliament Square, Downing Street and Whitehall.

Details of how they will convey their message and disrupt the city have not yet been revealed, although the theme for the action is 'regenerative'.

"This rebellion – set to be at least five times larger than what was seen in April – is our moment to rebel, above all, in the name of repairing the wounded organism that is our planet, our communities, and ourselves," a spokesperson said.

"During this rebellion we will try to demonstrate the change we want to see in society – to show how we can nurture a new culture that is resilient and robust."

After 6,000 people shut down the five main bridges over The Thames last year, thousands more took over large parts of London in April.

(Image: PA)

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Large groups of people swarmed roads in a bid to stop traffic, while protesters lay down at the base of a large pink sailing boat that was anchored in Oxford Circus.

By the end of 11 days of demonstrations 1,130 people were arrested.

Organisers claim that 4,000 people have signed up to get themselves arrested this time as the environmental activists attempt to cause more of an impact.

They may have slightly been hindered in this effort by a police raid of a props warehouse stationed in the old Lambeth County Court on Saturday.

Officers used a battering ram to knock down the front door, arresting eco-rebels inside and confiscating items including solar panels, gazebos and wheelie bins.

Extinction Rebellion have found success in the past year by staging colourful and visually impacting protests.

Last week they drove a fire engine towards the Treasury and sprayed fake blood from one its hoses - a malfunction with the equipment ensuring a great pool of claret formed beneath the building.

(Image: REUTERS)

(Image: REUTERS)

The move aimed to highlight the UK government's pursuit of perpetual economic growth - something that necessarily uses up finite resources - and the £2 billion of financial support fossil fuel projects overseas received from the Treasury last year.

They also hope to extract attention with the diverse protesters that have joined the cause.

A group of retired police officers were amongst those on the streets of London in April, with one retired detective getting himself arrested by refusing to get off Waterloo Bridge.

Elderly people have also joined the fight in large numbers.

Phil Kingston, an 83-year-old grandfather of four, said: “I fight with all my being for my four grandchildren in this situation of existential danger. And I am a Christian who cares for the Earth as God’s Creation; and for the world’s poorest peoples whose experience of injustice draws a special love from God.

(Image: SWNS)

(Image: Dan Kitwood)

“I come to the Treasury to challenge these practices and to demand radical change in them. In particular the proposal of the Climate Change Committee that UKEF works towards zero emissions by 2050 is far too late.

"Greta Thunberg stated to the United Nations on 23rd September that the CO2 budget for giving a 67% chance of staying within 1.5 degrees C will be entirely gone by 2028 at current emissions levels.”

As well as their emission centered demands, Extinction Rebellion are calling on the Government declare a climate and ecological emergency.

They also want to see the Government create and be led by the decisions of a Citizens' Assembly on climate and ecological justice.
description: At open ceremony attended by 1,000 people the climate change activists told of plans to force the Government to act with their demonstrations
